metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Coronavirus-19 Disease (COVID-19): A case series of early suspects reported and the implications towards the response to the pandemic in Zimbabwe Category of paper -Case report(series) Title -Coronavirus-19 Disease (COVID-19): A case series of early suspects reported and the implications towards the response to the pandemic in Zimbabwe

abstract.text: Zimbabwe is among the countries that have been identified to be at risk of the COVID-19 2 pandemic. As of the 15 th of March 2020, there has been no confirmed case of the virus. 3

body_text.text: The studies conducted to date have shown African countries to be at risk of getting the new 21 coronavirus disease , mainly due to their close link with China 1 . Despite the 22 associated high risk, the number of reported cases has been rising slower than anticipated 23 considering their weak health and emergency preparedness and response systems 2 . Several 24 conspiracy theories have been proposed to explain the fewer cases, but they are yet to be 25 proved 3 . The Africa continent has not been complacent but has started to put in strategies 26 to curb the pandemic 4,5 . According to the World Health Organisation (WHO) report on 27 COVID-19 on the 15 th of March 2020, 365 cases were confirmed in 25 African countries. The 28 mortality rate in Africa currently stood at around 2% 6 . Zimbabwe is among the countries 29 that have been identified to be at risk of COVID-19 virus 1 . As of the 15 th of March 2020, 30 9700 travellers had entered the country through all the port of entries. Of all the travellers, 31 only 14 COVID-19 diagnostic tests have been performed, and none has tested positive. 32 Some of the suspected cases have attracted national-level attention in various media 33 forums, especially social media. The COVID-19 pandemic has been associated with a lot of 34 misinformation 7 . The authorities are now issuing regular official statements to update and 35 allay fears of the public. The eight cases presented here are based on official reports made 36 to the public by the authorities. The information was obtained from the update reports 37 shared with the public 8-15 . The aim was to appraise the general screening, case 38 management, and preparedness of the country regarding COVID-19. consequences. The first case was referred to a psychiatrist for suspected psychological 48 trauma. The 3 rd case initially absconded COVID-19 testing later return after police report. 49 The 5 th case was reported by the hotel where he was staying despite being asymptomatic. i.e., more testing more cases identified. Testing widely will also enable the country better

FIGREF2.text: 99 to assess the extent of circulation of the virus. To date, most of the confirmed cases in Africa 100 are imported. Whether community transmission has started and the extent is not known, 101 hence the limitation of the continued use of travel history. Evidence has now shown cases 102 without travel history to China being detected in some developing countries 22 . 103 104 There are possible explanations of why the country might not be testing as many suspects as 105 possible. The main possible reason should the unavailability of the COVID-19 diagnostic 106 tests. The actual number of COVID-19 tests available in the country is not open to the public. 107 However, reports of donations from development partners without specifying the exact 108 amounts have been made 12 . The other reasons might be due to the weak screening 109 procedures at the ports of entry; poor adherence, incorrect interpretation or use of the 110 WHO screening criteria and complexed of COVID-19 testing. Currently, there are no studies 111 that have been conducted to validate the WHO screening criteria. The use of the word "test" 112 might be misleading considering the several complex steps (many of them manual) involved 113 in COVID-19 diagnosis. COVID-19 testing to date involves Reverse Transcription Polymerase 114 Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) technology 23 . The process has to be done by a qualified laboratory 115 scientist or technician, and at each step, quality control protocols are followed to ensure an 116 accurate and precise result. Like any other developing countries, Zimbabwe is not spared 117 from the shortage of diagnostic equipment and the required skilled personal. invested significantly in the capacitating of the diagnostic laboratories and 121 isolation centres in preparation for the COVID-19 pandemic. The National Microbiology 122 Reference Laboratory (NMRL), capacity to test for COVID-19 and sub-national laboratories in 123 efficient specimen collection, handling, and processing was assessed and found to be 124 satisfactory. A system to sent specimens to South Africa for confirmation was established. 125 One of the suspected cases had a sample successfully sent to South Africa verification. The 126 country established three major isolation centres in Harare at WIDH, Bulawayo at 127 Thorngroove Hospital and the tourist town of Victoria Falls at Victoria Falls Hospital. In 128 terms of the necessary equipment and infrastructure, the most developed and supported is 129 the one at WIDH. All the isolation have challenges of intensive and critical care unit beds in 130 case of severe complications. None of the centres has a functioning ventilator. Infection 131 control has been a challenge at these isolation centres due to shortages of personal 132 protective equipment(PPE) 24 . Reports of them initially relying on space suits, gloves, 133 gumboots and N95 respirators acquired when the country was preparing to fight an Ebola 134 outbreak in 2014 were made but these quickly ran out. Development partners have also 135 donated some, but shortages continue to be experienced 24 . Although there is a lack of PPE, 136 infection prevention and control protocols have been developed across the cascade of 137 COVID-19 care in line with WHO guidance 25,26 . On top of the isolation centres, COVID-19 138 Rapid Response Teams have been set up at all levels throughout the country. Each of the ten 139 provinces has a COVID-19 Rapid Response Team responsible for first-line follow-up and 140 tracking of suspect cases and organising the necessary referral to the isolation centres. 141 These teams have been very responsive, as reflected by how they responded to the has been conducted among health workers at all levels in the different 145 regions of the country in the case management of COVID-19. The skills were further 146 enhanced with the experience gained from the suspected cases. However, three of the 147 cases who experienced mental illness and stigma (which might have led to the other patient 148 abscond testing and the other being reported by the hotel despite being asymptomatic) 149 indicate that these social, psychological, and mental consequences of COVID-19 should be 150 considered as part of case management. Research conducted in China has shown the 151 psychological impact associated with the diagnosis of COVID-19, notably the isolation and 152 quarantine 27 . Several incidents of Chinese nationals being stigmatised and discriminated in 153 other countries just because the virus originated in China have been reported 28 . 154 155 The patient who developed mental illness reported to a public health facility while she was 156 still under the 21-day follow-up, thereby posing the risk of infection to the other patients 157 and health care workers. Available evidence has shown that patients with an initial negative 158 result can later test positive 29 . This mistake brings into doubt whether the authorities are 159 earnestly following-up all patients under self-quarantine at home. If the home visits were 160 being performed, the mental issues would be identified early, and the patient referred to a 161 psychiatrist more safely. The mistake that one of the suspects absconded the isolation 162 facilities before testing should not be taken lightly. Such patients have the danger of 163 initiating community spread of the virus. 164 165 Like what most African countries have done, the President has declared the coronavirus as a 166 national disaster. A COVID-19 National Preparedness and Response Plan was also launched. 167 Major events planned at the national level (Zimbabwe International Trade Fair and the 168 independence celebrations) were cancelled, schools and tertiary institutions will be closing 169 early. Social distancing continued to be promoted while gatherings of more than 100 people 170 were banned 30,31 . The local authority in Harare with support from development partners 171 set up several mobile hand washing points within the city. The city also started the city-wide 172 spraying of bus terminus, restaurants, pavements and other public places. The available 173 evidence regarding the spraying of cities to prevent coronavirus is conflicting. There might 174 no benefit in high-temperature countries like Zimbabwe 32,33 . There has been a debate on 175 whether the country should start implementing some of these infection and prevention 176 control without a case yet recorded. Experiences from countries affected early on China and 177 Italy, have shown that it is better to be overprepared than not to prepare at all 34,35 . The 178 WHO has created four transmission scenarios(no cases included) and countries are 179 encouraged to prepare according to their context 36 . to the COVID-19 pandemic. There is a need to enhance the screening process 184 and infrastructure at all ports of entry. Travellers should be screened based on their point 185 origin as opposed to the departure airport of the aeroplane. Ports of entry, especially at the 186 borders, should be equipped with the necessary standard screening equipment and human 187 resources. Follow-up of patients on self-quarantine should be strengthened so that 188 complications or seroconversion are picked on time. Systems to track and trace contacts 189 should be in place to enable robust follow-up across all possible points of transmission along 190 the chain 37,38 . Efforts should be made to increase the number of laboratories with the 191 capacity to test for COVID-19 together with the necessary human resource support. This 192 should be accompanied by procuring more diagnostic test kits to increase the health care workers on mental, social, and psychological consequences of COVID-196 19 should be urgently implemented. Efforts should be made to assess these consequences 197 early on and support offered promptly since COVID-19 diagnosis can be traumatising. 198 Awareness should be given to the public and service providers against stigma and 199 discrimination of national from the source countries. The security at the isolation centres 200 should be improved to prevent cases from escaping leading to community transmission. 201 Increasing and equipping intensive care units at both the isolation centres and nearby 202 central hospitals should be prioritised especially with the ventilators. Respiratory distress is a 203 common complication of COVID-19. Procurement of personal protective equipment for the 204 isolation centres should be urgently prioritised. Awareness through various media on the 205 importance of general hygiene practices (hand washing and avoiding touching of the face) 206 should continue.

Only 44 two suspects had a travel history to China. Of the 8 cases, only 1 met the WHO criteria of a45    suspect, but four were had laboratory test for COVID-19 performed. However, all four tests46    were negative. Three of cases (1 st , 3 rd and 5 th ) experienced mental, social, and psychological

TABREF1.text: The screening at the Zimbabwe ports of entry has been strengthened. This is reflected in the 67 number of suspected cases detected so far. Initially, travellers coming from affected will be going for them to follow-up the traveller for 21 days. As part of the follow-up, the 78 local health authorities will be submitting regular feedback to the national level in a 79 prescribed format. However, the well-structured screening process seems to be only80 available at Robert Mugabe International Airport. Reports have been made on substandard 81 screening points at the border ports of entry 19 . Though authorities have conducted 82 assessment visits, these border ports of entry still have human resources and equipment The country might not be testing enough considering the number of travellers received visa 87 vee the number of COVID-19 tests conducted to date. There are suspected cases who were 88 not tested despite them having high-risk travel history and reported to a health facility. The 89 country managed to perform a paltry of 14 COVID-19 diagnostic tests since the beginning of 90 the outbreak. Anecdotal reports from observers have highlighted that some immigration 91 officials were not checking the travel origination point. Some of them only focused on the 92 plane's prior departure airport, thereby allowing many travellers to enter with incomplete 93 travel history 20 . A few of the suspects were also not screened after failing to meet the WHO 94 suspect criteria. This failure to screen might have been proper considering the limited 95 resources. However, if resource permits, WHO recommends testing broadly (test, test and 96 test), including patients who do not strictly meet the case definition 21 . Experiences from the 97 other affected countries have shown the number of cases identified is related to the testing,

TABREF2.text: The authorities in the longer run, depending on how the pandemic will 207 evolve, should consider a lockdown, restricting travel further or close borders to high-risk 208 countries. A lot is still unknown across the COVID-19 cascade of care (prevention, screening, 209 diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis). More research is needed to offer evidence-based 210 solutions 39 . Most urgently is the support towards the development of COVID-19 point of In conclusion, the Zimbabwean authorities and supporting partners should be decisive and 214 move with speed in addressing the highlighted challenges and gaps. In the neighbouring 215 country, South Africa, more than a dozen cases have been reported, and its matter time 216 before cases start to surface in Zimbabwe. For that to happen, there is a need for financial 217 resources. To date, the United Kingdom Government's Department for International Development, World Health Organisation, Ecobank, Mimosa Mine, Global Fund, Chinese Government, the Government of Zimbabwe, developing partners among others have 220 pledged resources towards the pandemic. More partners and stakeholders should come on 221 board if the country is to win the war against the COVID-19 pandemic. The author would like to appreciate the Ministry of Health and Child Care (MoHCC), Harare City Department of Health and COVID-19 Rapid Response Teams in various parts of the 227 country who have been in the forefront in responding to the pandemic and providing the 228 necessary information and updates to the country. Finally, the author is grateful to 229 suspected cases whose information was used for the appraisal. The COVID-19 Updates reports used to summarise the suspected case are available to the 232 public and can be accessed from Zimbabwe, Ministry of Health and Child Care (MoHCC) The author has no competing interests. 24.
